014package org.jdbi.v3.sqlobject.locator;
015
016import java.lang.reflect.Method;
017import java.util.function.Function;
018
019import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.ConfigRegistry;
020import org.jdbi.v3.core.locator.ClasspathSqlLocator;
021import org.jdbi.v3.sqlobject.internal.SqlAnnotations;
022
023/**
024 * Locates SQL in {@code .sql} files on the classpath for use with {@link org.jdbi.v3.sqlobject.statement.SqlQuery}.  Given a class and method name, for example
025 * {@code com.foo.Bar#query}, load a classpath resource name like {@code com/foo/Bar/query.sql} and use it with the annotation. The contents are then parsed,
026 * cached, and returned for use by a statement.
027 *
028 * @see org.jdbi.v3.core.locator.ClasspathSqlLocator
029 */
030public class SqlObjectClasspathSqlLocator implements SqlLocator {
031
032    private final ClasspathSqlLocator locator;
033
034    public SqlObjectClasspathSqlLocator() {
035        this(ClasspathSqlLocator.removingComments());
036    }
037
038    public SqlObjectClasspathSqlLocator(ClasspathSqlLocator locator) {
039        this.locator = locator;
040    }
041
042    @Override
043    public String locate(Class<?> sqlObjectType, Method method, ConfigRegistry config) {
044        Function<String, String> valueOrMethodNameToSql = key -> {
045            String filename = key.isEmpty() ? method.getName() : key;
046            return locator.locate(sqlObjectType, filename);
047        };
048
049        return SqlAnnotations.getAnnotationValue(method, valueOrMethodNameToSql)
050            .orElseThrow(() -> new IllegalStateException(String.format("method %s has no query annotations", method)));
051    }
052}
